slides.title: Welcome to Galaxies and Cosmology
slides.content:
# Introduction to Galaxies and Cosmology

Welcome to **Galaxies and Cosmology** - the large-scale universe!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Galaxy Types** - Spirals, ellipticals, irregulars
- **Galaxy Evolution** - How galaxies change
- **The Big Bang** - Origin of the universe
- **Dark Matter and Energy** - The invisible universe
- **Fate of the Universe** - How it might end

> **Fun Fact:** There are more galaxies in the observable universe than grains of sand on Earth!

slides.title: Galaxy Classification
slides.content:
# Galaxy Classification

## Hubble Sequence (Tuning Fork):

| Type | Shape | Features |
|------|-------|----------|
| Elliptical (E0-E7) | Spheroidal | Old stars, little gas |
| Spiral (Sa-Sc) | Disk + arms | Young stars, gas, dust |
| Barred Spiral (SBa-SBc) | Spiral + bar | Central bar structure |
| Lenticular (S0) | Disk, no arms | Intermediate |
| Irregular (Irr) | No structure | Gas-rich, chaotic |

## Numbers:
- ~70% are spirals
- ~20% are ellipticals
- ~10% are irregulars

slides.title: Spiral Galaxies
slides.content:
# Spiral Galaxies

## Structure:
- **Nucleus:** Dense center, old stars
- **Bulge:** Spherical, old stars
- **Disk:** Flat, spiral arms
- **Halo:** Globular clusters, dark matter

## Spiral Arms:
- Sites of star formation
- Young, blue stars
- Density wave theory

## The Milky Way:
- Barred spiral (SBbc)
- ~200-400 billion stars
- ~100,000 light-years diameter
- ~2,000 light-years thick (disk)

slides.title: Elliptical Galaxies
slides.content:
# Elliptical Galaxies

## Properties:
- Spheroidal shape (E0-E7)
- Old, red stars
- Little gas or dust
- No ongoing star formation

## Size Range:
- Giant ellipticals: Millions of light-years
- Dwarf ellipticals: Thousands of light-years

## Formation:
- Result of galaxy mergers
- Spirals merge -> Elliptical

## Examples:
- M87 (giant, hosts massive black hole)
- Cen A (radio galaxy)

slides.title: Galaxy Interactions
slides.content:
# Galaxy Interactions

## Types:
- Fly-by: Tidal distortions
- Collision: Pass through each other
- Merger: Combine into one

## Effects:
- Tidal tails and bridges
- Triggered star formation (starbursts)
- Central black hole growth
- Transformation of galaxy type

## Andromeda-Milky Way:
- Approaching at 110 km/s
- Collision in ~4.5 billion years
- Will form "Milkomeda"

## Starburst Galaxies:
- Extreme star formation
- Often from interactions

slides.title: Active Galactic Nuclei
slides.content:
# Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN)

## Definition:
- Supermassive black hole accreting
- Extremely luminous center

## Types:

| Type | Properties |
|------|------------|
| Quasar | Very distant, very bright |
| Seyfert | Spiral galaxy, active nucleus |
| Radio galaxy | Powerful radio jets |
| Blazar | Jet pointed at Earth |

## Unified Model:
- All are same phenomenon
- Viewing angle determines appearance

## Supermassive Black Holes:
- Every large galaxy has one
- Millions to billions of solar masses

slides.title: The Big Bang
slides.content:
# The Big Bang Theory

## Core Idea:
- Universe began ~13.8 billion years ago
- Expansion from hot, dense state

## Timeline:
| Time | Event |
|------|-------|
| 0 | Big Bang singularity |
| 10^-43 s | Planck time |
| 3 min | Nucleosynthesis (H, He, Li) |
| 380,000 years | CMB released |
| 400 million years | First stars |
| 13.8 billion years | Today |

## NOT an Explosion:
- Space itself expanding
- No center, no edge
- Everything was everywhere

slides.title: Evidence for Big Bang
slides.content:
# Evidence for the Big Bang

## 1. Hubble Expansion:
- Galaxies receding from us
- Farther = faster
- v = H x d

## 2. Cosmic Microwave Background:
- Afterglow of hot universe
- 2.725 K blackbody
- Nearly uniform (+/- 0.00001 K)

## 3. Light Element Abundances:
- 75% H, 25% He by mass
- Matches predictions

## 4. Structure Formation:
- Tiny CMB fluctuations
- Grew into galaxies

## 5. Time Dilation:
- Distant supernovae last longer
- Confirms expansion

slides.title: Dark Matter
slides.content:
# Dark Matter

## Evidence:
- Galaxy rotation curves
- Galaxy cluster masses
- Gravitational lensing
- CMB fluctuations

## Properties:
- ~27% of universe
- Doesn't interact with light
- Only gravity detected

## Candidates:
- WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles)
- Axions
- Primordial black holes

## Distribution:
- Halos around galaxies
- Web-like structure (cosmic web)

slides.title: Dark Energy
slides.content:
# Dark Energy

## Discovery:
- 1998: Type Ia supernovae observations
- Expansion is ACCELERATING
- Nobel Prize 2011

## Properties:
- ~68% of universe
- Causes accelerated expansion
- Nature unknown

## Possibilities:
- Cosmological constant (Lambda)
- Vacuum energy
- Quintessence (varying field)
- Modified gravity

## Equation of State:
- w = P / (rho x c^2)
- w = -1 for cosmological constant
- Current measurements: w ~ -1

slides.title: Fate of the Universe
slides.content:
# Fate of the Universe

## Possible Scenarios:

| Scenario | Description |
|----------|------------|
| Big Freeze | Expansion forever, cold death |
| Big Rip | Dark energy tears apart everything |
| Big Crunch | Gravity reverses expansion |
| Big Bounce | Crunch followed by new bang |

## Current View:
- Big Freeze most likely
- Dark energy dominates forever
- Stars burn out, galaxies isolated
- Heat death in ~10^100 years

## Uncertainties:
- Dark energy behavior unknown
- Quantum effects at edges

slides.title: Large Scale Structure
slides.content:
# Large Scale Structure

## Cosmic Web:
- Galaxies not randomly distributed
- Filaments and walls
- Clusters at intersections
- Voids between

## Hierarchy:
- Galaxies
- Galaxy groups (~50 galaxies)
- Galaxy clusters (~1000 galaxies)
- Superclusters
- Cosmic web filaments

## Local Group:
- Milky Way + Andromeda + ~80 others
- ~10 million light-years across

## Observable Universe:
- ~93 billion light-years diameter
- ~200 billion galaxies

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Galaxies and Cosmology Summary

## Galaxy Types:
- Spiral: Arms, disk, young stars
- Elliptical: Spheroidal, old stars
- Irregular: Chaotic

## Big Bang:
- Universe began 13.8 billion years ago
- Evidence: CMB, expansion, abundances

## Composition:
| Component | Percentage |
|-----------|------------|
| Dark energy | 68% |
| Dark matter | 27% |
| Ordinary matter | 5% |

## Fate:
- Big Freeze most likely
- Eternal expansion

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Galaxies and Cosmology!
